revision.text:
[[File:125 mm ampoule thrower finnish army test.jpg|thumb|Finnish troops testing the weapon in 1941]] [[Image:125 mm ampulomet battle of stalingrad museum.jpg|thumb|Ampulomet on display at the [[Museum of the Battle of Stalingrad]].]]
The '''Ampulomet''' ({{lang-ru|125-мм ампуломёт образца 1941 года}}, also rendered ''Ampulomyot'', ''ampulla mortar'', etc., lit. "ampule/vial thrower" cf. миномёт) was an expedient [[anti-tank weapon]] which launched a 125mm incendiary projectile made of spherical glass.<ref name="Argentina)1945">{{cite book|author=Círculo Militar (Buenos Aires, Argentina)|title=Revista|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cHwPAAAAIAAJ|year=1945|publisher=Calle de Viamonte.|page=562}}</ref><ref name="Rottman2007">{{cite book|author=Gordon L. Rottman|title=Soviet Rifleman 1941-45|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XTc2Ffyt_X0C&pg=PA30|year=2007|publisher=Osprey Publishing|isbn=978-1-84603-127-4|pages=30–}}</ref> This weapon was introduced in 1941 and used (to a limited degree) by the [[Red Army]] in [[World War II]], but by 1942 was largely obsolete.<ref name="Rottman2005">{{cite book|author=Gordon L. Rottman|title=World War II Infantry Anti-Tank Tactics|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vCwV1bC47-cC&pg=PA47|year=2005|publisher=Osprey Publishing|isbn=978-1-84176-842-7|pages=47–}}</ref>
The weapon weighed approximately 28 kg, and fired a 1.5 kg<ref name="Glantz2005">{{cite book|author=David M. Glantz|title=Companion To Colossus Reborn: Key Documents And Statistics|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rAJnAAAAMAAJ|year=2005|publisher=University Press of Kansas|isbn=978-0-7006-1359-5|page=154}}</ref> projectile up to 250m, at a rate of 8 rounds per minute with a crew of 3.<ref name="ZalogaNess1998">{{cite book|author1=Steve J. Zaloga|author2=Leland S. Ness|title=Red Army Handbook 1939-1945|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=efRmAAAAMAAJ|year=1998|publisher=Sutton Pub.|isbn=978-0-7509-1740-7|page=197}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Northover Projector]], an analogous British weapon produced for the Home Guard
